The movie's atmosphere actually was similiar to Junction.Still, as I'm not a fan of violent movies in general I do remember a bit much of that and I also remember just not being comfortable with certain scenes. I guess this is a movie that kind of holds you to your seat and presents itself so strongly that it really doesn't matter whether you like it alot, you'r just compelled to watch.I may have to watch this one again, I'm not sure how the movie would appear to me now and if I'd still feel that way after so many years but if I had to describe "Wild at heart" I'd have to say you may not love the movie but you can't stop watching if you start. Definetly a really odd film.

Review title: "What The Hell Was That All About?"
Review_body: Wild at Heart is less a movie and more a psychological journey. It's hard for me to judge it the way I judge other movies; it simply can't be put under the same standards. Most movies are about entertainment and telling a story; this movie (like Blue Velvet before it) is about intense emotions, the darker side of the soul, and the warped mind of director David Lynch. David Lynch is one of the few directors left who still expresses himself through his work; he is one of the last true film artists. He indulges himself here, perhaps to an extreme. I'm not even sure I can say that this movie "entertained" me in the usual sense; but I relished the experience.Personally, I think they do a great job-it is meant to be humorous, and it works as a perfectly good counterpoint to the increasingly sinister obstacles they must overcome. Here is where the movie really shines: Lynch lets his imagination run wild in his depiction of a bizarre and dangerous underworld of criminal activity. Willem Dafoe is pitch-perfect as the sleazy hit-man, and the scene where he tries to seduce Laura Dern in the hotel room is one of the most disturbing moments of sexual tension ever caught on film. As with most David Lynch films, there are so many small details, so much humor and intelligence (as opposed to your average Hollywood hit) that it can be enjoyed over and over again. All in all, I think "Wild at Heart" is an underrated movie that, while far from Lynch's best, is very enjoyable. It is well-filmed and -directed, and there is a feeling of strength and energy that makes the film even more appealing.Overall rating: 7 out of 10.

Review title: Definitely Not a fan of his...
Review_body: But I can acknowledge how directors took real risks back then. Without the fear of social media backlash and political correctness hysteria. So for that reason only, I give this movie more stars than I intended to. Some actors gave great performances in all this nonsense ness, so you can add this to the list of pros. This and the soundtrack that broadcasted one of my favorite songs of all time, in a very unexpected way. Are reasons that kept me watching and be both intrigued and appalled. But I guess that was the point, was it?...

A romantic comedy for people who would never admit they like romantic comedy: a romance for the grunge set replete with lots of flowing blood, guns going off, cigarettes apuffing, and slimy bit characters met on the lam. David Lynch directs with snap and shock and a devious sense of humor, but I think he ought to have the courage to make a romantic comedy straight out. He splashes guts and rubs our face in vomit to disguise the simple love story so his leather and chains audience can imagine they're seeing life in the raw instead of being seduced as their parents so often were by yet another Hollywood romance.Nicholas Cage plays Barry Gifford's Sailor like a dumbed-down Elvis Presley (and that was before he grabbed the microphone), and Laura Dern as Lulu captures well the mentality of a sweet, shallow, but meat-eating little thing who just wants to have fun. When I first saw her in Smooth Talk (1985) (from a story by Joyce Carol Oates) I thought she was just flat out sexy, but here she seems a little dull even if she does have "breasts that stand up and say hello." Diane Ladd, as Lulu's mother, employing some Phyllis Diller shtick, is funny as the wicked witch of the east on testosterone.What saves this movie from the ridiculous is the fact that the poor saps, Sailor and Lulu, really love each other. He makes her "hotter than Georgia asphalt," and he finds her "dangerously cute." They have a whole bunch of mindless love-but maybe that's the best kind.(Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon!)

After 'Twin peaks: fire...' I was up for another Lynch film and I had only 'Wild at heart' to pick. Compared to 'Twin...' this one comes off slightly silly at times (as do Lula and Sailor - again, at times), but for the greater part it is still a wonderful film. The (love & hate) story is basically straightforward (with a few too many flashbacks when things are pretty obvious anyway), but the hardships which Sailor and Lula have to endure, add the extra layer. The best example - and also one of the best scenes of the film - is when Lula encounters Bobby Peru in the motel room; though Willem Dafoe also shows us that he is a better actor than Nicolas Cage (even if Cage is better for the part of Sailor).'Wild...' has many bonus characters that do not add much to the story, but they do add to (the atmosphere of) the film, as do some haphazard scenes, like the one when they encounter a survivor at a car accident. Need I add that Lula by Laura Dern is one the hottest roles in the history of film? Done.A big 8 out of 10.

Review title: Beautiful, violent, funny and surreal--a masterpiece from David Lynch
Review_body: This is one of my favorite David Lynch films. It is also one of the more transparent, easy to understand Lynch films, although that's not the reason why it's one of my favorites. But that fact also makes Wild at Heart a good candidate for introducing someone to Lynch.On the other hand, although it's more transparent and linear on a surface level, I'm still not sure I've figured out the multilayered, bizarre subtexts and symbolism that lie deep beneath the surface--even though I've seen it a few times now. Assuming that there is indeed something to figure out. To an extent, it seems like maybe the hint of something "deeper" is in this case more of a red herring. This is one of Lynch's funnier films, albeit very macabre humor. It contains references to all of Lynch's most common "content quirks"including sequined ingénues singing jazz, manipulative housewife types, shots of asphalt speeding by, minor characters with freaky speech "impediments", severed body parts, and on and on--but it's almost as if he's making fun of himself. Combine that with excellent performances (including a hilarious bit part for Crispin Glover, one of my favorite actors/personalities), a sublimely incongruous score, and a retro, gripping, violent road trip saga cum romance that presages both Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers (1994) and just about all of Quentin Tarantino's career, and you've got quite a film.Wild at Heart, based on a novel by Barry Gifford, is the tale of Sailor (Nicolas Cage) and Lula (Laura Dern), a doe-eyed, "classy white trash" couple. As the film starts--and what a start it is--someone tries to stab Sailor to death as he's exiting a theater. Sailor will have none of it, and Lynch begins the film on an exhilarating, brutally violent note--this is not a film for the faint of heart. To complicate matters and set up the primary conflict, we learn even before the attempted stabbing that the hit man was sent by Lula's mother, Marietta Fortune (Diane Ladd), who claimed that Sailor tried to seduce her in the bathroom (this isn't quite true, as we learn in detail later).There isn't a character in the film who isn't involved with some shady business, either presently or in the past. Sailor and Marietta's tensions stem from many years ago, when Lula was just a girl (she's supposedly quite a bit younger than Sailor). The events of the film's opening result in Sailor being imprisoned. Lula dutifully waits for his release, much to the consternation of her mom. The basic gist of the film is disarmingly simple--Sailor and Lula are headed across the country, with an eventual goal of California, as Marietta tries to arrange for Sailor to be put away for good. There are many finely realized subplots and detailed tangents, but that's the crux of the plot on the surface.In addition to his typical hyperreal/surreal weirdness, Lynch concocts a very improbable stew of influences that work together beautifully. Lula has something of an obsession with The Wizard of Oz (1939). She's haunted by visions of the wicked witch (including the "evil cackle"), and she sees the road trip as a veritable journey to the Emerald City. Lynch works in a lot of subtle references to The Wizard of Oz with other characters, too. Sailor is something like lounge version of Elvis reincarnated as a gangster flunky, with even better karate moves to match. Yet the two are huge heavy metal fans, especially of a band named "Powermad", whose music exquisitely punctuates many sequences, including some sublime dance scenes. In the first half, important scenes are set in New Orleans, with the familiar unsettling undertone that that locale often has in films--you can just smell the voodoo, sex, drugs and death bubbling beneath the skin of the city. Later scenes are set in the desolate, desert prairie country of Texas, which turns out to be even more unsettling (even though I really find such places refreshing and relaxing). There are other kinds of symbolic, stylistic and literal references worked into the film, such as the constant fire motif, which Lynch shoots beautifully, but the above is to just give you an idea of the stew.It all seems like it should add up to some subtextual grand narrative, and maybe it does, but I haven't quite figured out what it all means yet. But it doesn't matter. The stylistic flourishes are ingenious superficially, too, and maybe Lynch _is_ just poking fun at being Lynch. Here, perhaps more than in any other work, he has found the perfect balance between the soap-operatic and the utterly bizarre--the filmic equivalent to author Harry Crews' best work.Tarantino doesn't tend to have pithy subtexts in his films, either, but they're no worse the wear for that, and when Wild at Heart takes a turn into typical Tarantino territory, Lynch is just as captivating, gritty and groovy, plus he's doing it before Tarantino himself. At the same time, Lynch manages to maintain a parallel lush, erotic romance between Sailor and Lula--Dern is incredibly sexy/sensuous here. This material works as well, and supplies what just may be the message of the film after all--that love can (eventually) conquer all, even the stuff that's "wild at heart and weird on top".

"Wild At Heart" is an entertaining fantasy about a rebellious couple in love who go on the run to escape the troubles and violence which have blighted their lives in the past. On their journey they share passion, danger and conversations about their backgrounds as they get to know each other better. Theirs is a story which is heavily steeped in pop culture as illustrated by the movie's soundtrack, the numerous allusions to "The Wizard Of Oz" and their Elvis and Marilyn personas but it's also a story of hope as they try to escape to a better and more peaceful life together.Sailor Ripley (Nicolas Cage) and Lula Pace Fortune (Laura Dern) are very much in love but Lula's mother Marietta (Diane Ladd) will go to any lengths to keep them apart and so hires a thug to kill Sailor. Sailor kills his assailant in self defence but ends up in prison after being found guilty of manslaughter. On his release, Lula meets him at the gates and in an act which violates the terms of his parole; they decide to run away to California.The extremely determined and completely unhinged Marietta responds to this situation by hiring one of her boyfriends, a private detective called Johnnie Farragut (Harry Dean Stanton) to find the couple and bring Lula home and then later hires another boyfriend Marcellus Santos (J.E.Freeman) to kill Sailor.When the couple reach Big Tuna, Texas, Lula is pregnant and they start to run short of money. Sailor gets to know a criminal called Bobby Peru (Willem Dafoe) and then later agrees to carry out a robbery with him. Peru is a reckless psychopath who threatens to rape Lula, unnecessarily shoots two people during the robbery and also sets Sailor up to be killed because he'd been hired to do so by one of Santos' gangster associates called Mr Reindeer (William Morgan Sheppard).Sailor is subsequently given a five year sentence for his part in the robbery and on his release, Lula meets him with their son. An important decision then has to be made about what's best for the family's future and the course of action that Sailor takes is determined by an extraordinary and fantastic intervention from a very unexpected source.Nicolas Cage is sensational as he portrays his character's ability to be brutal and violent as well as charming and caring. His Elvis-style drawl and his renditions of two of the King's ballads are terrific and the way he delivers some of his great lines is brilliant and hilarious at the same time. Examples of this are his speech about the significance of his snakeskin jacket, the occasion when he exclaims "rockin' good news" and also when he says to Lula "the way your head works is God's own private mystery".Lula is strangely naive but also profoundly damaged by being raised in a family where both her mother and her cousin Dell (Crispin Glover) were insane and where her mother arranged to have her father killed in a fire. Add to this her childhood experience of being raped and having an abortion and the extent of her psychological baggage becomes clearer. Laura Dern captures Lula's contradictions and spontaneity perfectly in a performance which is absolutely flawless throughout.Diane Ladd's performance as the mad and murderous Marietta is wild and powerful and she dominates the screen every time she appears in the action."Wild At Heart" was directed with great flair and adapted for the screen (from Barry Gifford's novel) by David Lynch whose style is both colourful and surreal. Lynch's preoccupation with all things eccentric, bizarre and off-beat can often be unsettling or extremely funny but in the case of this movie is especially effective as it complements the fantastic and fairytale quality of the material so perfectly.
A celebration of sexism, stupidity, and sadism. And that's only the first fifteen minutes. If I were you I'd pull the plug. Give it a D.

Review title: Mr. Lynch's mastery is present in every single frame. What brings down his movie is that his story is only potentially interesting
Review_body: There is a scene in David Lynch's "Wild at Heart" that, I think, defines the meaning of the word classic. Nicolas Cage, perfectly matched to the role of an Elvis-like tramp in a snakeskin jacket, actually sings "Love Me Tender." Mr. Cage does his own singing and man, does he have a voice! The scene, beautifully shot and magnificently directed by Mr. Lynch, is mesmerizing. If this isn't memorable, then I just don't know what is. However, paradoxical as it sounds, this very scene is evidence of the film's downfall. How come? Because not only is this the best scene in the movie, it's the one where the credits are scrolling over. The last shot in the movie upstages everything that came before it.The sad thing is that this parody/homage to "The Wizard of Oz" based on a novel by Barry Gifford (which I have not read) suffers from a story that is only potentially interesting. As it opens, Sailor Ripley (Mr. Cage) kills a hit-man coming after him with a knife and is sentenced to prison. Upon being released, he and his girlfriend Lula (Laura Dern) embark on a wild and rampant road trip composed of them dancing, drinking, and lovemaking...a lot. All would be going well for them, if it weren't for the fact that Lula's mother (Miss Dern's real-life mother, Diane Ladd) is still out to see Sailor dead.How does this resemble "The Wizard of Oz"? Well, without giving too much away, it accomplish it because it Mr. Lynch is, probably without doubt, the most daring surrealist in the business today. And his craftsmanship and humor is omnipresent at all times. Some have objected to this picture because of its violence or its, to quote one critic, "sly excuses." But that is not what bothers me about "Wild at Heart." What made it fall flat for me was because, in spite of Mr. Lynch's mastery, there was very little of anything for him to really work with here.The first half of the movie is essentially a retread of the same thing. We see Sailor and Lula on their erotic adventures and we see the mother, Marietta, scheming and planning. That wears thin rather quickly. In the second half, we get a little more energy and a little more going on, with some plot twists, but by that point, I was completely exhausted by the redundancy of what preceded it.There are great performances in the movie. Mr. Cage and Miss Dern are sexy and work extremely well together. Miss Ladd, nominated by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for this film, is superb and screen-commanding, Harry Dean Stanton makes for yet another excellent straight man, and Willem Dafoe is absolutely brilliant as a sneaky, snarling scoundrel with an eye for trouble. The lovely Isabella Rossellini also makes a small appearance. But none of these actors, in spite of their talent, have interesting characters or dynamics to build themselves up on. The central love story between Sailor and Lula is only passionate in ostensible terms; there is little in the name of chemistry here. Miss Ladd's motives are cheap and sometimes hard to follow, making her a dismissible villain. Mr. Dafoe is interesting while he's on screen, but is forgotten as soon as he's not anymore.The movie just rumbles along like the characters' cars, going over the same territory and scenario again and again. When a twist comes, and we have to wait a whole hour for that, it's intended shock is dumbed down by the monotonous nature of what came before it. The dialog, written by director Lynch, shows traces of the wit that he so magnificently assembled in "Blue Velvet" but only traces. On and on it goes up until its great ending scene. And once that had concluded, I sat there aghast for I had realized a key flaw in the movie. There was a long-going plot element involving Miss Ladd and a couple of monotonous baddies played by J.E. Freeman and William Morgan Shepphard, and out of the blue, the movie completely forgot about it. Was it intended? I don't know and frankly, I don't care because it meant so little when compared to the amass of boredom I had to suffer through.There are some very fine moments, especially the ending scene, and again, Mr. Lynch's mastery is evident in every single frame. But "Wild at Heart" suffers from a dumbed-down story lacking any real passionate spark and instead of dousing me with excitement, plunged me into ennui within twenty minutes. It's endurable, but not memorable. It's not up there with Mr. Lynch's greats like "The Elephant Man" and, what I feel is his best, "Blue Velvet." Toward the end, there is a scene, completing Mr. Lynch's homage to "The Wizard of Oz" where a characters lectures to Mr. Cage that he should never "turn away from love." That's good advice. Better advice would be to turn away from this movie.

No one goes into a David Lynch movie expecting a normal viewing experience.But what do you come out with when you've seen a movie that cross-breeds a road movie with "Bonnie and Clyde", "The Wizard of Oz" and "Blue Velvet" (Lynch's previous film)?  Headache, nausea, dizziness and slurred speech, that's what.This is not a movie, it's a litmus test for how far a movie can go and how much it can get away with.  And obviously, the MPAA didn't let it get away with TOO much.  But enough, to be sure.As Sailor (Cage) and Lula (Dern) make their way through a bizarre world replete with oddball characters, twisted situations and nihilistic scenes of violence, it's kind of hard to juxtapose these with scenes of Glinda the Good Witch and Dern clicking her heels to get back home. 
Lynch tries to make a joke of the whole thing: blood, guts, severed hands and heads and all, but this is the kind of humor you're more apt to get if you're into jokes about death, dismemberment and a lack of overall morals. 
The only scene I did like in this whole mess is set in a dance club, where Cage roughs up a guy trying to put the moves on Dern, makes him apologize, has the guy get himself a beer and then jumps up with the band and breaks into an Elvis song while the girls in the club squeal and scream for joy. Seeing Cage sing like Elvis is worth the price of admission itself.Almost.One star.  For sheer guts, this movie has no equals, thank goodness.  But though it's "Wild at Heart", its "Heart" is not in the right place.  Just like its brain.

Review title: Lynch's equivalent of "True romance" is a gem
Review_body: (74%) In a world with so many movies barley amounting to very much in terms of tone and mood we have this early 90s Lynch classic that overflows with it. The film has a real ability to be darkly funny then instantly plain dark in such a way that you question exactly what is was you just chuckled at only a few seconds ago. The bleak dark grime is intermixed with a beacon of bright light and beauty so it never becomes overly oppressive despite some real nastiness and although clearly not for everyone (too many on- screen mental break downs and revolting characters for some), it still remains unquestionably well made and superbly acted proving Lynch to be a real genuine talent.

Review title: Very experimental, but not Lynch's best
Review_body: Throw all preconceptions of what you think a movie should or can be before watching David Lynch's disturbingly bizarre and highly experimental Wild at Heart. Everything comes loose for this odd tale of romance, horror, and disgust. It's about an oddball couple named Sailor and Lula, played excessively by Nicholas Cage and Laura Dern respectively. Sailor has just gotten out of jail and so he and Lula decide to break his parole and drive cross country to places like New Orleans and the little town of Big Tuna, Texas. Lula's mother hires a strange assortment of assassins to track down her daughter and her boyfriend and kill him. From here we are unexpectedly delivered a grotesque amount of shocking twists and turns that make you cringe with every strikingly disgusting moment of the film. It can be enjoyed, but it can also tip the film off the deep end into insanity, turning it into an in-cohesive and disturbing mess of a film. It's very raw and very experimental on Lynch's part, and I can respect him for that, but the final outcome left me feeling disturbed and deranged, rather than impressed.I can't bring myself to say that Wild at Heart is a bad film. It's not. It has lots of issues, but they are all issues brought about by Lynch developing a lot of his surreal and twisted style that he has perfected since then. Wild at Heart is very unpolished and unperfected, and that is something that definitely keeps it interesting. It is a very surreal experience, but so much so that you get lost in what it is trying to accomplish. The film is excessively weird and relies a lot on shock value from the audience. There are a lot of incredibly bizarre moments that break any and all cohesion this film has and it just drives it deeper into its deranged self. Lynch uses this film to experiment and toy with the art of cinema and storytelling through the abstract and surreal. The final outcome may have not been all there, but his motives are clear and the goal of the film is in sight, just slightly out of reach because of all the ridiculous oddities strewn about in the film.The characters in this film are just as bizarre as the style in which Lynch portrays them. The two leads are very disgusting and obscene characters that are hard to like, and they are also just plain weird. They aren't good people and they aren't respectable people. Plus the actors portraying them make them into caricatures more than multi-dimensional characters. Laura Dern acts her heart out, but plays it up in the most insane and wacky manner. Nicholas Cage takes it a step further and plays Sailor as the most overzealous and obnoxiously excitable character. I couldn't stand him. I'm not a Cage fan anyways, but his performance in this film was just ridiculous. The rest of the cast feel like adrenaline fueled nut jobs as well. I didn't feel any sympathy or remorse for any of the characters, but they are definitely strange enough to give the film its consistently off beat feel.The bottom line is that this film is insane. It gets pretty lost in itself, and definitely takes a dive into the dark pit of insanity. You have to be prepared going into this film because it is unlike anything you've seen before, as is the case with David Lynch films. Wild at Heart is a difficult film to get immersed in and you will certainly spend a lot of your time doing double takes and questioning why some of the bizarre and chilling depictions of sex and violence are being displayed on your screen and what ultimate purpose they are serving. This film has a right to be part of David Lynch's lineup of films though because it has a lot of bearing on where Lynch's style would go from there. The film is so surreal and so experimental that it loses a lot of its impact, but if you look at it through an experimental and artistic lens, it plays an important role in the David Lynch legacy. I didn't love this film but I can't hate it either. And as with most David Lynch films, I definitely feel like Wild at Heart deserves a few more viewings before I write it off as just another film.

Review title: Nice movie but with a disappointing ending
Review_body: "Wild at Heart" is a road-movie from David Lynch which tell us the love story between Lula (Laura Dern) and Saylor (Nicolas Cage). It's a thriller about a twisted story of love, death, murder and betrayal, but it ends in a very smooth and romantic way It's the first time I saw "Wild at Heart" from the beginning to the end. I had already seen some parts of the movie before, but I hadn't seen the whole movie. On one hand it surprised me a bit since it's closer to the "usual" kind of cinema by David Lynch than I initially thought: It has mysterious and bizarre characters, close camera shots, weird dreams, uncontrolled burning flames, excellent soundtrack (and perfectly combined with the scenes), and many other features that we can see in other Lynch's films. But on the other hand I was disappointed by its ending This movie, unlike his recent films, has a straight plot, one "easy" to understand, but OK, I was expecting it, so there's no problem about thatbut that ending! It really disappointed me! So smooth, so romantic, so sweet I can't recognize David Lynch there! With a different and more "Lynchian" ending I would score this film with a 9/10, but because of that I can't score it more than 8/10!

Review title: Pretty average sex, violence and romance movie - with some cult appeal.
Review_body: A sexy young lady (Lula)  and a young man (Sailor) formerly convicted of manslaughter hit the road - much to the disgust of the young ladies' mother who was rather he was dead!David Lynch's work has covered the full spectrum of cinema and has gained marks (from me) from the  high (The Elephant Man 9/10) to the low (Dune 2/10) so maybe this is the perfect one for the middle.Here Lynch does his usual act of peppering the proceedings with bizarre, unstable and  off-beat characters that you either love, hate, or love to hate. This is clearly a bit of a make-weight given that the plot is pretty thin (almost a standard road movie with bells and whistles)  and not altogether life affirming. One of these movies that presents the 9-2-5 world as boring so "why not go out and rob a bank instead?"I was very forgiving when I first saw this movie because it has enough plot and action to let you slide along with it, but it fails to hit the heights because I didn't really like anybody all that much, even the sexpot Laura Dern turned me off after a while with her smoking and yack-yack-yack. It gets sillier and more immoral as it goes along, but it had to because it had said everything it had to say pretty early in the piece and had no where else to go.As I said before - not good, not bad, somewhere in the middle...

Review title: Inventive, bleak romance drama has power
Review_body: A real stimulatingly offbeat exhibition from Lynch is the dark and wild backdrop of a romantically engaged traveling pair: "Sailor" who is on parole after committing a brutal murder, and "Lula" whose mother demands her to return from a spoiled trip to Texas with help from a detective. It's a twisted, artsy journey that is often repulsive and long to boot (and certainly not for the squeamish!), but fares inventive at a certain degree and boasts some of the strongest performances ever worked on a Lynch film, perhaps even in 1990. Cage's concert act and the magically rendered semi-ending are two classic acclaims put together in this moving cinematic collage. RATING: * * *
Wears its name on its sleeve, but manages to be quite reserved for a lynch film.

This one just might take the cake in the "absurd comedy" genre.  Nicholas Cage is Elvis and Laura Dern is Dorothy (her real life mother plays the Wicked Witch) in this post-modern allegory on fairy-tales and violence. Being a Lynch movie, this is never out-right said, only implied through image and action.  Having been made in 1990, and subsequently winning the top prize at Cannes, the film was latter ravaged by critics yet paved the way for a string of films in the mid-1990's that defined a generation of film-makers lead by the likes of Tarantino.  There never would have been a reception for "True Romance," "Pulp Fiction," or "Natural Born Killers" if it weren't for Lynch's folly that actually plays pretty well (and with much hilarity) all these years later now that this genre seems to have run itself into the ground.  Kudos to Dafoe for out-Dafoeing himself and making himself truly the ugliest character to ever grace the screen (those teeth! that death scene! WOW).  Also, an oddity for Lynch, in that it seems to have an overtly happy (and rocking good time!) ending.  A must for Lynch fans, or anyone who love the movies they love more than they love Movies.

Review title: Not to be confused with ITV's rubbish
Review_body: "Wild At Heart" is my first real taste of a David Lynch film. The only other film of Dave's I've seen is "The Elelephant Man" and although it is an extraordinary and moving film, it restricts David's trademark weirdness and motifs as it's based on a tragic true story. I've been wanting to get a taste of David Lynch for a while because I'm into weird, over-the-top films and so when "Wild At Heart" popped up on ITV (not the crap wildlife drama) I had to give it a record. I have to say that I was pretty impressed and I'm looking forward to other films her has to offer.I would describe Lynch's style as Quentin Tarantino on acid. It's even more over the top in its editing, directing and music than most Quentin films. I absolutely loved Wild At Heart's energy, it has a fantastic pace and doesn't remain dull for a moment until it reaches its final half hour or so. The beginning keeps you immediately hooked with its fantastic over-the-top pantomime characters, especially the mother who is played with psychotic and sometimes frightening spirit by Diane Ladd. Nicholas Cage gives a typically wooden performance, whereas his partner (Laura Dern) in crime has a much more likable spirit.It's just a shame that the film seems to lose its focus about more than halfway through. The mother suddenly becomes absent and her presence is lost. The twisty and revealing flashbacks also go a miss, making the viewing less gripping. Things also start to feel repetitious when the duo encounter the car accident, the formula of dance, have sex, drive begins to where thin and the introductions of more hit men become incredibly confusing and surreal! However, there is a great use of colour throughout with the red and yellow conveying the idea of flames to create a clever fiery atmosphere.When the duo meet the super creepy Willem Dafoe (looking unbelievably frightening- prepare to have nightmares) the pace starts to slow and it's only the scenes with Willem that gain attention as things begin to lose focus. Although, there is a a fantastically creepy robbery sequence that will stay with you for an eternity. After this things begin to rebuild its focus, building up to a brilliant and clever finale.I also liked the "Wizard of Oz" references dotted throughout and its use of music. Overall, it's certainly a film that is worth seeing and if the film didn't lose its focus and had a good ten minutes cut down, then I'm certain that I would be branding this a masterpiece. However, unfortunately it doesn't quite reach that status despite it still being tremendously likable. I shall look forward to "Mulholland Drive" and "Blue Velvet" especially from Lynch.EDIT: Having now watched and loved Inland Empire, Twin Peaks (1/4 through series 2) and Mulholland Drive (which is now one of my favourite films of all time) I am, professionally speaking, in love with David Lynch. When I revisited Wild At Heart again last night I enjoyed it much more than the last time. I liked how the pace slowed down in the second half with Willem Dafoe as it gave the film a more dream-like quality which is something David is incredibly good at doing. Although, I still wouldn't brand Wild At Heart as a masterpiece, it still isn't far off and I'd urge people who've only seen it once to see it again in a different light.

Review title: What do you know, a Lynch film worse than Dune
Review_body: As bad as Dune was, it had some interesting acting, and some of the book's ideas survived the transfer to film, and you could connect to Paul Atreides. Clearly marked heroes and villains make a passable film. I don't know what to make of this noisy mess, there's lots of swearing, sex, filthy language, drinking, smoking, violence, bodily fluids, none of which has any context to anything, it's just there for shock value I suppose. What possible purpose do multiple references to vomit on the floor serve? Several characters remark about the smell and discuss the presence of the vomit, and there's a closeup of it in case you need a reminder of what vomit looks like, but Lula, a paragon of delicate femininity, doesn't bother to clean it up. All of the characters are ugly, misshapen caricatures incapable of depth, humanity, continuity, or clarity. Diane Ladd's performance is interesting I suppose, but her character's motivations have nothing to bounce from, it's all crazy, all the time; it's nothing special, I can see that down at the bus station. Give me a reason for the lunacy and I can connect with it. The Elephant Man didn't have to make sense, the common thread that ran through the film grounded it, and all the artistic flights of fancy returned to the central theme. Same thing with Eraserhead, it's a dream, I get it. But Wild at Heart is a mess from beginning to end.

By 1990, David Lynch was the foremost surrealist of US cinema, a position cemented by Eraserhead, Blue Velvet and his long-running cult TV series 'Twin Peaks', a bizarre deconstructed soap. As a director-for-hire, he'd also displayed versatility for tackling more mainstream fare as evinced by The Elephant Man and Dune, with plaudits for the former and critical brickbats for the latter.Lynchian cinema was more popular in Europe than on his home turf, and came to be synonymous with the perception of the director himself, a former all-American boy (and latterly, Ronald Reagan admirer) distorted by a funhouse mirror to resemble, as Elephant Man producer Mel Brooks wryly observed, "Jimmy Stewart from Mars". The repressed, ultra-conservative "I Like Ike" generation had some very peculiar stuff in its closet. Lynch made it his currency.After 'Twin Peaks', expectations were at fever pitch for Lynch's next project. The director came across Barry Gifford's novella 'Wild At Heart' while still in its proofing stages and fashioned a loose adaptation in six days. Unusually for Lynch, the script's pretty straightforward and chronological; as Wild At Heart star Dafoe noted later, "I was always shocked at how logical it was - its world was so complete." But as ever, El Diablo's in the details.Here, Blue Velvet's yuppie nightmare becomes a white trash ticket to Hell: reckless Sailor Ripley (Cage, in full-on Elvis mode) loves hopeless romantic Lula Fortune (Dern), which drives Marietta Fortune (played by Dern's real-life mother Ladd) round the twist. After her lascivious advances to Sailor are spurned, she sends a hit-man after him, who Sailor kills - graphically, smashing his skull to splinters. On release from prison and defying his probation for "manslaughter", Sailor and lusty Lula hit the pedal for California, encountering all manner of Lynchian freaks en route. Unbeknown to them, Lula's insanely jealous mother has hired seedy PI Johnnie Farragut (Stanton) and various thugs to hunt them down, culminating in a stand-off in one-horse-town 'Big Tuna' with evil gunman Bobby Peru (Dafoe).A dream turning inexorably to nightmare, Wild At Heart's an all-out assault on the senses, aided immeasurably by Angelo Badalamenti's fantastically smoky score. But the director's trademark oddities (from obese prom queens and cockroach-bothering relatives to Ladd's hellish, red lipstick-covered face) seem forced, and unlike Eraserhead there's scant emotional heart.With deliberately over-the-top performances (from Ladd and Defoe, particularly), characterisation always takes a back seat to knowing iconography, along with campy references to The Wizard Of Oz - Dern imagines Ladd as the Wicked Witch of the West, while 'Twin Peaks' star Sheryl Lee portrays Glinda.Nevertheless, amid catcalls and cheers - and much to Lynch's bemusement - the film won the Palme d'Or at the 1990 Cannes Film Festival; a fitting opener to a decade which would see the director's post-modern riff on American pop-culture become de rigeur in independent US cinema, ultimately achieving more cross-over successes than Lynch ever imagined.

Perhaps David Lynch's chef d'oeuvre, this film works so well in so many layers one might be left satisfied by only having paid attention to the slightest and most obvious one - the love story. The final scene has already made it to the pantheon of the most recognizable ones in cinematic history. But of course, if it was only that, it wouldn't be a Lynch movie. Dark humor, unpredictability, gratuitous gore, great angles and fantastic music (from metal to Elvis to classical) compose the whole picture. Let's not forget Willem Dafoe, an unbelievably cool character with one of the best deaths depicted on celluloid!

For such a downright bizarre film, Wild at Heart has got a surprisingly large cult following. Even though its wacky, surreal and completely out there, people love debating this film. They love to ponder it. And I must confess...so do I.If you're familiar with David Lynch's work, then you know what a kooky filmmaker he is. He's right up there with Tim Burton. Maybe even more so. A lot of Lynch's films come with an absurdist atmosphere that is at times infuriatingly difficult to crack. But it is worth the effort. Beneath the surrealism and oddball characters packed into his films is a rich and fascinating subtext. And Wild at Heart is one of Lynch's most absorbing efforts.Wild at Heart takes the basics of a road trip formula, and transforms it into a stunning journey of self-expression as well as discovery. Lynch would explore this territory again to equally breathtaking effect in the beautifully resonant The Straight Story, by far his best film.The film focuses on a modern day pair of star-crossed lovers, Sailor Ripley and Lula Fortune (Nicolas Cage & Laura Dern). Lula is dominated by her obsessive control freak of a mother, Marietta (Diane Ladd, Dern's real life mother). But Sailor opens Lula's eyes to a world beyond her mother's front door. Alas, Sailor ends up in prison for two years after he kills a man sent by Marietta to kill him.While on parole, he hooks up with Lula, and the two set off on the journey of their lives. All the while, Marietta sends numerous PI's and hit men after them to kill Sailor once and for all.It may take some time for Wild at Heart to work its magic over you. Because its quite a difficult film to enjoy at times. But it is a near-masterpiece. You just have to look hard enough.All the most rewarding moments are between Cage and Dern. Their scenes together crackle with a real voracious, sexual kick. And Lynch knows that too. He shoots many of their lovemaking scenes in a dangerous red. To the point that it becomes unbearable. These are lovers with energy to burn. Which might explain the frequent closeups of smoked cigarettes to symbolise that point.And Lynch utilises Angelo Badalamenti's musical score to exhilarating effect. Alternately moody. Wistful. Tragic. The music is so accessible and perfectly attuned to the material it almost tells a story in of itself.Of all the films Nicolas Cage has starred in, Wild at Heart must count as his finest. The character of Sailor is a part that fits him like a glove. A travelling dreamer who defiantly defends his individuality in a world out to crush his free-thinking spirit. And although Sailor has no desire for violence, he is prepared to use it when he sees which way the wind is blowing. Cage also gets to show off his surprisingly fine singing voice. Doing some pretty nifty Elvis impersonations.Laura Dern is also at the top of her game here. At first glance, Lula appears to be a brainless piece of trailer-trash. But Lynch uses an interesting technique of multilayered flashback sequences to penetrate the levels of Lula's past. And over the course of the film, through a combination of Dern's acting and Lynch's direction, Lula engages your sympathies without you even realising.Diane Ladd turns in an astonishingly broad performance that threatens to teeter into parody at any moment. But the surprising thing is, her OTT theatrics are quite in character. That may go over your head the first time. But she does know when to dial it down. Her relationship with her daughter is quite an astute blend of domineering control and genuine concern. Although it may take several viewings before you pick up on that.Wild at Heart is punctuated with frequent layers of bizarreness. Some hover at the edges. Others spill over into the narrative. Such as Willem Dafoe's Bobby Peru, a detestable louse who ropes Sailor into crime. The scene where he corners Lula in a motel room, threatening her into sexual submission is not only alarming, but physically draining. You are quite relieved when that scene is over.The film is also mind-bogglingly obsessed with the Wizard of Oz. References crop up everywhere. Sailor and Lula's road-trip is compared to the Yellow Brick road. In Lula's mind, her mother resembles the Wicked Witch of the West. And at the height of inspired lunacy, Sailor receives a divine vision from Glinda, the Good Witch of the North (played by none other than Twin Peaks' Laura Palmer!), who inspires him to renew his relationship with Lula.As things draw to a close, it seems for a time our hopes for Sailor and Lula's love will be dashed. And Lynch does a superb job making it seem that way. But the final scene, when Sailor sings Love Me Tender to Lula, the song he promised to sing to his wife is a scene that's quite lovely. And you realise its a moment the whole film has been building up to. I love the way it plays out over the end credits. It ends the film on the perfect note.Touching. Disturbing. Never less than inspiring, Wild at Heart is a searing love story beautifully played by all. And one of David Lynch's most intriguing films to date.

I dont know why, but I really liked this movie, there didnt seem to be much substance, but somehow it managed to be a great movie.  Maybe it was seeing all of those famous actors in unusual roles(especially Dafoe).  Nicholas Cage played his character perfectly, as did Laura Dern.  David Lynch's direction kept this movie very entertaining.  They should make more little movies like this.  ***1/2 out of *****.

A love story, David Lynch style. Sailor and Lula on the run from Lula's off the wall mother. Even more off the wall is some of the characters and situations in this film. There are a lot of references to "The Wizard Of Oz," including a visit from The Good Witch! Nicholas Cage and Laura Dern are hot as Sailor and Lula, but it's Diane Ladd as Lula's momma, that steals the film (And should have won the Oscar for supporting actress). If you are a TRUE Lynch fan, then you can understand a lot of the weirdness going on ("Twin Peaks" was on during this period, too). Best parts: The story of "Jingle Dell," with Crispin Glover; Bobby Peru (Willem Dafoe) with Lula and ANY scene with Diane Ladd. There's a lot of unexpected violence (The first few minutes are INCREDIBLY VIOLENT!)that may gross you out, but it is an incredibly good film, especially the music.

Filled with some crazy characters, this one certainly catches your attention and refuses to let go. Nicolas Cage is at his best playing the larger than life Sailor Ripley and Laura Dern does a great job as Lula. I thought Diane Ladd as Marietta was truly excellent and Willem Defoe was also great as the sleazy Bobby Peru. You cannot fail to notice the many references to 'The Wizard of Oz'; a theme that runs throughout. Unfortunately I found the film ran too long, there's only so long you can put up with all the craziness. It reaches a point where we lose one of the main threads that have been running through the first two thirds of the film and I found that quite distracting. Still, it's worth a look for a decent Cage performance and the, almost comic-book, like characterisations from Lynch (well at least for the first two thirds).SteelMonster's verdict: RECOMMENDEDMy score: 6.9/10.You can find an expanded version of this review on my blog: Thoughts of a SteelMonster.

I'm getting closer and closer to seeing all of David Lynch's films and only have about two full length films and one short away from that feat. He truly is my favorite director and amazes me with just about every film he does. This movie disturbed me quite a bit but also blew me away and it is a great addition to my David Lynch collection.I thought the story of Wild at Heart was the greatest part, which should be true with any great film. It is disturbing and intense with awesome references to Elvis and The Wizard of Oz. It is bizarre but much more accessible than most of his films. And though I prefer his ambiguous films, this is definitely top notch as well.Acting doesn't get much better than this. Laura Dern is awesome as well as Diane Ladd, Willem Dafoe, Harry Dean Stanton and even Nicolas Cage, who I usually hate. They were all wonderful and really brought a lot of life to their characters. Lynch really understands how to direct actors.Lynch fans will be pleased with this romance/thriller. See it soon if you fall into that category.

Review title: Charmous, weird and fascinating. This is Wild at Heart.
Review_body: In the early screenings of 'Wild at Heart', it was extremely bad received, with about 80 persons walking out of it in the first two days, whose a good majority of them were complaining mostly about the graphic and gruesome depiction of violence, or the intense sex scenes,and even about the crude profanities spelled in the film. What a poor reasons. Seriously, it's a great film regardless if it is too strong or not. It's a very good film. And i'll say why it's so good.Lynch's use of references of the pop culture such as the popular fantasy film Wizard of Oz and the Elvis Presley's films fits well in the environment of Wild at Heart. It even softly calms down a few tense situations, due to an spoof feeling on it. The abundant use of the 'hot' colors in this film, to portray a 'wild' atmosphere, are masterfully used as well. The plot it's everything but clever though. This is somewhat obvious,because we're talking about David Lynch, whose content of his films are always expected to be very obscure. But if it helps, Lynch himself said that the film's main intention is to show 'how to love in the hell'. I really think he did the mission very well then. So, in a short resume, Wild at Heart is a film full of pointless dialogs, pop references, sex and violence, all mixed with a stunning cinematography. If you are planing to watch it, i highly recommend you to do so. 8.3/10

Unlike everyone says, "Wild at Heart" is far from being David Lynch's worst film. Actually, there is a part of me that even thinks it's a masterpiece. As a parody, it doesn't have the gloomy atmosphere of "Blue Velvet", but personally, I found it even more extreme and uncompromising. I understand that it could be a bit too much to handle though: the cartoonish characters and the cheap soap opera overacting that characterized Twin Peaks are not for everyone, and the pulpy sex and gore make everything feel even more grotesque. I mean, people's brains getting blown out, continuous Wizard of Oz references, and Nic Cage singing Elvis songs and dancing with karate chops at a power metal gig, all in the same movie! Retrospectively we can describe it as a Tarantino-style movie, but we should not forget that Tarantino was not even close to debuting at the time "Wild at Heart" was shot.The plot is partly based on the pulp-noir novel of the same name, and is overall pretty straightforward: Lula and Sailor are two rebels in love who decide to hit the road so that no-one can drive them apart anymore. Lula's mother is an evil witch who sends a private eye and a hitman after them. Lynch decides to add all kinds of weird diversions along the way, with some of the craziest, creepiest characters he ever created. More than the original story itself, these diversions are the things that make the film truly memorable. Unlike "Twin Peaks" and "Blue Velvet", there is no light to balance the sleaze and darkness, no coffee and cherry pie after the nightmare. Lula and Sailor are naive and madly in love, but they just feel like cheap and shallow caricatures, you couldn't care less about them.I understand that the movie aims at creating a world and characters rather than just telling a coherent story, but some focus on the plot wouldn't have hurt. Mr. Reindeer, the Durango gang and Marcellus Santos are iconic characters with their own story arcs, but the film forgets about them halfway through. Marietta even gets "erased" for convenience. Willem Dafoe as Bobby Peru is one of the creepiest Lynchian villains ever, but gets disposed of a bit too easily. It's like they shot what they could and then abruptly closed the film with a pre-made happy ending.Regardless, the countless iconic scenes and over the top pulp still make "Wild at Heart" one of my personal David Lynch favorites.

Review title: David Lynch gave us a story of a totally shattered society.
Review_body: David Lynch who was making the famous TV-series Twin Peaks, decided to make a film at the same year, called Wild At Heart. He used his usual crew, for instance Angelo Badalamenti who also composed the music for Twin Peaks. Laura Dern is also well known from Lynch's Blue Velvet (1987) and no one but Laura worked with David Lynch again from this crew. In a documentary "Il était une fois... Sailor et Lula" (2009) most of the people who worked with Wild at Heart told that the project was just so exhausting. Even Lauran Dern said that she was shattered after the film was finished.The movie is very hard to put in a genre (like most Lynch's movies), but I would consider it as a romance/drama/road-movie, since it deals with love and family issues on the road. People who mostly watch mainstream films, would probably find this movie sick and twisted. But for people who watch a lot of movies from Lynch or not, will probably find this very interesting, affecting and entertaining.It's about a criminal, called Sailor (Nicolas Cage) who runs away with her girlfriend Lula (Laura Dern) across the southern states. Lula's mother (Diane Ladd) sends few killers after Sailor to save her daughter. David Lynch has put the world of 1990 into Sailor and Lula's life. What we see in their life is a totally shattered family structure, a shattered society. Among this it deals with death, despair and how crazy all the people have gone.This obviously is a postmodern film and it's surrealism as most of Lynch's movies are. The music is also outstanding, modern and different. As I mentioned Lynch used the same composer (Angelo Badalamenti), that he used with Twin Peaks. But in addition to that, Lynch mixed some old Rock 'N Roll like Elvis with new Heavy Metal, which expressed the rage and frustration of the characters brilliantly.So David Lynch is dealing with reality through surrealism. His world view in this film is dark: the world full of misery, death, violence, hatred and horror. While watching you might think that David Lynch is sick, the whole movie is sick and that's the world view Lynch is showing. We're supposed to feel sick, the world around us is sick."This whole world's wild at heart and weird on top." This is what Lula Fortune said to Sailor Ripley and it's pretty much what this movie is about.I don't know why Wild at Heart has a low rating over here, maybe because of its originality (Not that low, but compared to other Lynch-films). In the documentary I mentioned before, they said that this movie was a flop in the United States but a big success in France. I can clearly see why, the narrative partly reminded me of the French style. And people in Europe are more used to artistic films, I'm not talking about all the people, but generally speaking.8/10 A great postmodern film, which also was Nicolas Cage's best performance. A violent story about the world we live in.

Review title: Unwatchable - Cage drags everyone else down!
Review_body: I can appreciate quirky films - if well done. This isn't. It's a typical Nick Cage film (barring the initial first few), in which the dialog is stilted, the acting high-schoolish. I can't believe Laura Dern and her mother - an Oscar winner - agreed to this film. I'm not sure why Lynch has a good reputation, as this film is just amateurish. Rarely do I not finish a movie, but couldn't take more than an hour of this crap

Review title: Joltingly violent, shockingly erotic retelling of `The Wizard of Oz'.
Review_body:
Upon hearing the words `David Lynch', dozens of words spring to mind. `Weirdo, bizarre, insane, articulate, violent, erotic, and above all else, crazy'. Such is the case with the cult classic `Wild at Heart'- the movie which epitomises his very existence. The styles and characteristics rank to a very acquired taste. If you are the slightest bit squeamish, then give this film a miss. But if you can take it, then you'll find `Wild at Heart' to be one of the oddest cinematic experiences in history.
The plot may seem simple enough, but there are plenty of surreal and indefinable elements thrown in, to make sure that you will not forget this movie for a long, long time. As he has done in the past, the notoriously perverse director explores the underbelly of sex and violence that lurks in southern America. He definitely succeeds in what he sets out to do  single-handedly destroy the American dream. Not only that, he tramples over it several times and then shreds it up in a lawnmower. The end result is a bleak, over-violent road movie given the extra surreal touches along with far too many ferociously explicit sex scenes. This is a very loose retelling of `The Wizard of Oz', and one that certainly won't have you look at the former the same way again. Our two main characters  Sailor and Lula are the star-crossed lovers who travel across the country (the road supposedly representing the Yellow Brick Road), much to the chagrin of Lula's mother (the Wicked Witch?). By the end, they've encountered many deranged psychos and even a delightfully odd visit from Glinda the Good Witch. For the most part, this is a guilty displeasure (if such a thing exists). One receives a voyeuristic sense whilst watching the movie. Instead of being compelling, this is more often mind numbing, but as the scenes become increasingly insane, you can't stop watching it. And by the end, it leaves a surprisingly good taste despite all that proceeds.
Never funny enough to make you laugh, never realistic enough to leave you shocked but never boring enough to have you repelled. It continuously dizzies the mind enough to make you believe that through all the blood and perversity, there is an invigorating story. Effectively eccentric performances all round from a good cast. Nicholas Cage, snakeskin jacket in tow, is always believable as the parolee- turned criminal. And what a beautiful singing voice (hee-hee). A 35-year-old Laura Dern doesn't for a second pass for a 20-year-old. But the accent is top-notch and the white-trash characteristics are exemplary. An Oscar nominated Diane Ladd makes for a thoroughly engrossing character. But Willem Dafoe steals the show as ultra-psycho Bobby Peru- intimidating, odd and psychotic. Underused support is generated from a supporting cast including Crispin Glover, Issabella Rossellini and Harry Dean Stanton. The abnormal bravura styles of David Lynch leave their mark, bringing the movie style, violence and surrealness, but no heart. A captivating, often insane and consistently shocking cinematic experience, this bleak oddessy through a hellish landscape is audacious and deserving of its status of a cult-classic. While it will probably only appeal to about 6% of the world, this is a dazzling, dark and strangely vivid movie. My IMDb rating: 7.4/10.

I still can't figure out the whole Wizard of OZ theme, but I dug the overall film.  Willem Dafoe, is of course, the standout in the film.
